Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: PSERC Collaborative Proposal for a Phase III Industry University Cooperative Research Center Program
Award.AbstractNarration:
PSERC is proposing a Phase III support (third five-year period) for the Center, including support for center personnel, evaluation and research. The proposed Center is a multi-university Center comprised of the following universities: Arizona State University (lead), Cornell University, Texas A & M, Howard University, Washington State University, the University of Wisconsin-Madison, Iowa S ate University, Wichita State University, Georgia Tech, the University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign, the University of California-Berkeley, and Colorado School of Mines.

The proposal from PSERC seeks funding for a Phase III (3rd five-year period) led by Arizona State University (ASU). PSERC had its origin as a multi-university IUCRC in 1996, and was created with the vision that collaboration amongst a large group of academic, industrial, and governmental institutions can develop solutions to the complex problems in electric energy. PSERC (currently comprised of 12 universities) will conduct research organized under three primary research stem areas: markets stem, system stem, and transmission and distribution technologies stem. PSERC leverages the expertise of some 40 multidisciplinary researchers. The PI and all of the other site directors are very well-qualified and have access to appropriate and adequate resources.

The proposed work addresses important improvements and advancements in the transmission and delivery of electricity. PSERC has been a leader in in developing several key concepts with regard to the development of electricity markets. PSERC researchers also developed one of the first large scale visualization tools for the electric power industry, and this effort has resulted in the creation of a company that has commercially developed the tool. Over the past six years, PSERC member companies have employed an average of 80 graduate and undergraduate students per year from PSERC universities. In the area of diversity, one of the PSERC member universities is Howard University, a historically black university. PSERC will continue to seek women and minorities through students and faculty at member universities as well as on an individual basis as research associates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The electric power grid is becoming more complex and has generated new challenges. Major operational, protection and economic challenges are generated from the variability of renewable resources, new inverter interfaced systems and new customer owned electrical resources. Under this project, new methods and technologies have been developed to address these challenges. Two of the innovations reached a developmental phase that led to field installations. These two major accomplishements are described next:

A new approach and methodology was developed for distributed dynamic state estimation using GPS synchronized and non-synchronized measurements. As shown in the DDSE image, the dynamic state estimator operates on the model of a substation which includes all the power apparatus in the substation as well as the power circuits (lines) connected to the substation. The presence of GPS-synchronized measurements (PMUs) enables the time tagging of the substation dynamic state which is time-tagged with precision of typically one microsecond. The substation state estimates are send to the controil center where the state estimates of each substation at the same time tag are assempled to synthesize the system wide dynamic state and display it via visualization methods. This approach is scalable to any size power system and it provcides the dynamic state of the system at speeds of 60 times per second. This is a breakthorugh. The method has been implemeted using advanced object oriented state estimation methods. This work resulted in major research projects sponsed by the DoE and utilities. Several demonstration projects were initiated on the US-VI electric energy system, Southern Company and NYPA.

A new approach for modern power apparatus protection, the settingless protection, has been invented, laboratory tested and presently under field testing. The method uses dynamic state estimation that operates on the dynamical model of the protection zone (transfomer, motor, line, inverter, etc.) and the samples voltages, currents, temperatures and other measured quantities obtained with digital data acquition. The dynamic state estimation provides a high fidelity operating condition of the protection zone. As an example the second image shows the visualization of a high fidelity electro-thermal model of a transformer obtained with the dynamic state estimator. Decisions to trip the protection zone depend on the operating condition of the protection zone. The method detects abnormalities within a few samples of measurements (much faster than phasor based legacy protection systems) and protects the zone from all abnormal conditions. For example for a transformer, it provides protection against internal faults, overexcitation, overloading, etc. with only one relay while legacy systems require multiple protection functions to protect one zone. This developement has been well received by the industry and a field demonstartion is under way in the NYPA system under NYSERDA sponsorship.

Above breakthroughs have been utilized to address a fundamental problem for electric energy systems with high penetration of renewables: stabilization of operation. Specifically, a new method has been invented for supplementary inverter control during power grid disturbances using as feedback signals the output of the dynamic state estimator (DSE). The DSE provides the frequency and rate of change of frequency at the inverter location as well as at the system that may be located miles apart. This feedback steers the operation of the inverter towards continuous synchronization with the power grid. Extensive high fidelity simulations using physical models have demonstrated the effectiveness of the approach.

Above achievements are fundamental building blocks for the modern smart grid and the smooth integration of renewables into the power grid.
